title: Dead link in 19.2
body:
The link to the trailing comma problem returns a 404:

https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/es5/README.md#commas

title: 6.2 contradicts 18.12
Error in 16.1
body:
Hello,

In 16.1, it says:

> Use braces with all multi-line blocks.

But in the examples, there's a contradiction:

```
// good
if (test) return false;
```

And

```
// bad
function foo() { return false; }
```

The second one shouldn't say 'bad' since it's not multi-line block like the rule says.

title: Explain why not to prefix methods with underscores
body: Fixes issue #1024

title: Why are underscore prefixes for internal methods of a React component considered bad?
body:
The third bullet under [react#methods](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/master/react#methods) says:

> Do not use underscore prefix for internal methods of a React component.

I was just wondering what the reasoning behind this was?

title: Correct es2015 named module example
body: See http://exploringjs.com/es6/ch_modules.html for an in-depth explanation

title: Fix issue with eslint-config-airbnb README.md file formatting
body: Just a small fix for `eslint-config-airbnb/base` subheading. **Before:** --- **After:**

title: Remove misleading reference to one-var eslint rule
body:
This eslint rule does not enforce this style guide rule. I believe that
referencing it here will cause people to believe that this is enforced
via linting when it is not. As far as I know, there is no rule that
currently enforces this, but it would be nice to add one.

Maybe you should delete one of the examples to make it more clear.

![2016-08-18 09_10_43-airbnb_javascript_ javascript style guide](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20089383/17765050/b8e37014-6523-11e6-9529-cc6f73898e4c.png)

title: Readme: No variable assignment chaining
body: Closes #221

title: Error: "Configuration for rule "react/jsx-sort-props" is invalid"
body:
Okay so just tried to update some packages, including some `eslint`-related stuff and __shock-of-shocks__ it broke stuff... So I removed everything (`rm -rf /node_modules`, cleared out `devDependencies` in `package.json`), thinking I'd just re-install everything from scratch using this dumb long-ass command `npm i -D eslint eslint-config-airbnb eslint-plugin-import eslint-plugin-react eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y`. Still broken (because I assume it tried to install the updated versions)... looks like something in the React package maybe?

![screen shot 2016-08-16 at 4 10 14 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4298089/17714156/952887e8-63cc-11e6-9dc9-9aaea83a5198.png)

Trying to use this as an `eslint` config is actually stupid though. The number of times I've installed all this shit using the above command, only to have it throw errors is _extremely_ frustrating. It's dependants should just be included and I shouldn't have to install all this extra bullshit just to use it. I understand the thinking behind it (what if not everyone wants the whole kitchen sink right) but clearly wider developer ergonomics were not a priority in designing this. Anyone have an alternative solution/one `eslint` config file will all the rules in it?

Anyway, for now I guess I'll just revert to whatever versions I was using before and just never update anything because who knows what might break tomorrow  ¯\__(ツ)__/¯

title: [Request] use constants for linter error levels
body:
My team has forked this project a couple times because linting rules are mostly 2/error instead of 1/warning, so it obscures genuine errors.

Something like this:

```
<Foo b={} a={} /> // props sorted wrong
```

Should not have the same severity as a critical bug! This adds a ton of mental overhead to every line when red dots are popping up everywhere: "will this code throw an error or is there some minor formatting issue?"

Needing to be so precious with every line slows down development when you may just be testing some additions or wading into third party code. 

Doubly with autofix enabled, Atom currently fixes a ton of formatting inconsistencies on save, I can safely ignore some warnings now.

However, I understand your logic in #853 – when you need to enforce absolute consistency in your team, saying "you can't proceed without fixing this niggle" is important. I would argue that should go in a commit hook or similar, but...

why not use a custom constant to define the error levels? This would allow the linting logic to be more flexible:

`{ rule: airbnb.ERROR }`

title: No rule for avoiding single letter names
body:
While the readme says: `Avoid single letter names. Be descriptive with your naming` https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#naming--descriptive

The rule is deactivated: https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/be6e13f7b91ede245602c9760d112905ac497dcc/packages/eslint-config-airbnb-base/rules/style.js#L48

What about activating the rules with min 2 characters?

title: Incorrect import/extensions settings?
body:
In [this commit](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/commit/b45fdcd60f6e08f13718bc2348e8d6ea1314e91c), the settings for `import/extensions` was added but this seems incorrect. I don't see that `node_modules` is a valid entry in the doc.

https://github.com/benmosher/eslint-plugin-import#importextensions

What does it mean exactly if it's valid?

title: [eslint config] [base] [breaking] Add no-plusplus in base errors.js and desc in README
body:
@ljharb  Added `no-plusplus: 'error'` to eslint-config-airbnb-base/errors.js in order to disallow unary increment and decrement statements.  In addition, added description under Variables in the main README. 

This PR references https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/540.

title: Invalid config for react/jsx-uses-react?
body:
I'm using atom, with the nuclide plugin and sometimes, the linter doesn't work.

Here's the error I see in the console:

```
/Users/tommy.leunen/.atom/packages/nuclide/pkg/nuclide-diagnostics-store/lib/LinterAdapter.js:20 Uncaught (in promise) Error: /Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/react.js:
    Configuration for rule "react/jsx-uses-react" is invalid:
    Value "[object Object]" has more items than allowed.

Referenced from: airbnb
Referenced from: /Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/.eslintrc
    at validateRuleOptions (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-validator.js:116:15)
    at /Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-validator.js:163:13
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Object.validate (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-validator.js:162:35)
    at load (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:523:19)
    at /Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:392:36
    at Array.reduceRight (native)
    at applyExtends (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:363:28)
    at load (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:530:22)
    at /Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:392:36
    at Array.reduceRight (native)
    at applyExtends (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:363:28)
    at Object.load (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config/config-file.js:530:22)
    at loadConfig (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config.js:64:33)
    at new Config (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/config.js:233:38)
    at CLIEngine.executeOnText (/Users/tommy.leunen/dev/project/node_modules/eslint/lib/cli-engine.js:748:28)
```

I don't override the `jsx-uses-react` rule.
eslint-config-airbnb@9.0.1 
eslint-plugin-react@5.2.2 

It looks like this happen when linting a file that doesn't have any JSX.

title: Eslintrc - wich one should i use ?
body:
Hi,

I'm implementing eslint to use the coding standard and it seems like your Javascript Coding Standard is pretty nice. So I installed eslint, eslint-plugin-import, eslint-plugin-react, and eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y (with npm). 

Then I follow your installation guide [Here](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb#eslint-config-airbnb-1). But I have too many .eslintrc

I don't know in wich one I should put the "extends": "airbnb".

> /usr/local/Cellar/node/6.3.1/libexec/npm/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/fs-vacuum/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/bower/lib/node_modules/extend/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/bower/lib/node_modules/form-data/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/bower/lib/node_modules/inflight/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/bower/lib/node_modules/request/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y/node_modules/jsx-ast-utils/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/eslint-plugin-react/node_modules/jsx-ast-utils/.eslintrc
> /usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/fs-vacuum/.eslintrc

EDIT : After searching more, I suppose it's the .eslintrc.js i create with the `eslint --init`

title: No more env: browser?
body:
Did something change recently in the `env` configuration?

I just updated to the latest version in one project and I'm getting a lot of `error  'document' is not defined  no-undef`.

This is resolved when I manually set the "browser" env in my config but I wonder why it's not done automatically here instead, like it used to be.

body:
